85 typedef Bounds_checked_array<Item *> Ref_item_array;

89 /**
90  Default condition filtering (selectivity) values used by
91  get_filtering_effect() and friends when better estimates
92  (statistics) are not available for a predicate.
93 */
94 /**
95  For predicates that are always satisfied. Must be 1.0 or the filter
96  calculation logic will break down.
97 */
98 #define COND_FILTER_ALLPASS 1.0f
99 /// Filtering effect for equalities: col1 = col2
100 #define COND_FILTER_EQUALITY 0.1f
101 /// Filtering effect for inequalities: col1 > col2
102 #define COND_FILTER_INEQUALITY 0.3333f
103 /// Filtering effect for between: col1 BETWEEN a AND b
104 #define COND_FILTER_BETWEEN 0.1111f
105 /**
106  Value is out-of-date, will need recalculation.
107  This is used by post-greedy-search logic which changes the access method and
108  thus makes obsolete the filtering value calculated by best_access_path(). For
109  example, test_if_skip_sort_order().
110 */
111 #define COND_FILTER_STALE -1.0f
112 /**
113  A special subcase of the above:
114  - if this is table/index/range scan, and
115  - rows_fetched is how many rows we will examine, and
116  - rows_fetched is less than the number of rows in the table (as determined
117  by test_if_cheaper_ordering() and test_if_skip_sort_order()).
118  Unlike the ordinary case where rows_fetched:
119  - is set by calculate_scan_cost(), and
120  - is how many rows pass the constant condition (so, less than we will
121  examine), and
122  - the actual rows_fetched to show in EXPLAIN is the number of rows in the
123  table (== rows which we will examine), and
124  - the constant condition's effect has to be moved to filter_effect for
125  EXPLAIN.
126 */
127 #define COND_FILTER_STALE_NO_CONST -2.0f
128 
129 static inline uint32 char_to_byte_length_safe(uint32 char_length_arg,
130  uint32 mbmaxlen_arg) {
131  ulonglong tmp = ((ulonglong)char_length_arg) * mbmaxlen_arg;
132  return (tmp > UINT_MAX32) ? (uint32)UINT_MAX32 : (uint32)tmp;
133 }
134 
135 inline Item_result numeric_context_result_type(enum_field_types data_type,
136  Item_result result_type,
137  uint8 decimals) {
138  if (is_temporal_type(real_type_to_type(data_type)))
139  return decimals ? DECIMAL_RESULT : INT_RESULT;
140  if (result_type == STRING_RESULT) return REAL_RESULT;
141  return result_type;
142 }
143 
144 /*
145  "Declared Type Collation"
146  A combination of collation and its derivation.
147 
148  Flags for collation aggregation modes:
149  MY_COLL_ALLOW_SUPERSET_CONV - allow conversion to a superset
150  MY_COLL_ALLOW_COERCIBLE_CONV - allow conversion of a coercible value
151  (i.e. constant).
152  MY_COLL_ALLOW_CONV - allow any kind of conversion
153  (combination of the above two)
154  MY_COLL_ALLOW_NUMERIC_CONV - if all items were numbers, convert to
155  @@character_set_connection
156  MY_COLL_DISALLOW_NONE - don't allow return DERIVATION_NONE
157  (e.g. when aggregating for comparison)
158  MY_COLL_CMP_CONV - combination of MY_COLL_ALLOW_CONV
159  and MY_COLL_DISALLOW_NONE
160 */
161 
162 #define MY_COLL_ALLOW_SUPERSET_CONV 1
163 #define MY_COLL_ALLOW_COERCIBLE_CONV 2
164 #define MY_COLL_DISALLOW_NONE 4
165 #define MY_COLL_ALLOW_NUMERIC_CONV 8
166 
167 #define MY_COLL_ALLOW_CONV \
168  (MY_COLL_ALLOW_SUPERSET_CONV | MY_COLL_ALLOW_COERCIBLE_CONV)
169 #define MY_COLL_CMP_CONV (MY_COLL_ALLOW_CONV | MY_COLL_DISALLOW_NONE)
170 
171 class DTCollation {
172  public:
173  const CHARSET_INFO *collation;
174  Derivation derivation{DERIVATION_NONE};
175  uint repertoire;
176 
177  void set_repertoire_from_charset(const CHARSET_INFO *cs) {
178  repertoire = cs->state & MY_CS_PUREASCII ? MY_REPERTOIRE_ASCII
179  : MY_REPERTOIRE_UNICODE30;
180  }
181  DTCollation() {
182  collation = &my_charset_bin;
183  derivation = DERIVATION_NONE;
184  repertoire = MY_REPERTOIRE_UNICODE30;
185  }
186  DTCollation(const CHARSET_INFO *collation_arg, Derivation derivation_arg) {
187  collation = collation_arg;
188  derivation = derivation_arg;
189  set_repertoire_from_charset(collation_arg);
190  }
191  void set(const DTCollation &dt) {
192  collation = dt.collation;
193  derivation = dt.derivation;
194  repertoire = dt.repertoire;
195  }
196  void set(const CHARSET_INFO *collation_arg, Derivation derivation_arg) {
197  collation = collation_arg;
198  derivation = derivation_arg;
199  set_repertoire_from_charset(collation_arg);
200  }
201  void set(const CHARSET_INFO *collation_arg, Derivation derivation_arg,
202  uint repertoire_arg) {
203  collation = collation_arg;
204  derivation = derivation_arg;
205  repertoire = repertoire_arg;
206  }
207  void set_numeric() {
208  collation = &my_charset_numeric;
209  derivation = DERIVATION_NUMERIC;
210  repertoire = MY_REPERTOIRE_NUMERIC;
211  }
212  void set(const CHARSET_INFO *collation_arg) {
213  collation = collation_arg;
214  set_repertoire_from_charset(collation_arg);
215  }
216  void set(Derivation derivation_arg) { derivation = derivation_arg; }
217  void set_repertoire(uint repertoire_arg) { repertoire = repertoire_arg; }
218  bool aggregate(DTCollation &dt, uint flags = 0);
219  bool set(DTCollation &dt1, DTCollation &dt2, uint flags = 0) {
220  set(dt1);
221  return aggregate(dt2, flags);
222  }
223  const char *derivation_name() const {
224  switch (derivation) {
225  case DERIVATION_NUMERIC:
226  return "NUMERIC";
227  case DERIVATION_IGNORABLE:
228  return "IGNORABLE";
229  case DERIVATION_COERCIBLE:
230  return "COERCIBLE";
231  case DERIVATION_IMPLICIT:
232  return "IMPLICIT";
233  case DERIVATION_SYSCONST:
234  return "SYSCONST";
235  case DERIVATION_EXPLICIT:
236  return "EXPLICIT";
237  case DERIVATION_NONE:
238  return "NONE";
239  default:
240  return "UNKNOWN";
241  }
242  }
243 };
244 
245 /**
246  Class used as argument to Item::walk() together with mark_field_in_map()
247 */
248 class Mark_field {
249  public:
250  Mark_field(TABLE *table, enum_mark_columns mark) : table(table), mark(mark) {}
251  Mark_field(enum_mark_columns mark) : table(nullptr), mark(mark) {}
252 
253  /**
254  If == NULL, update map of any table.
255  If <> NULL, update map of only this table.
256  */
257  TABLE *const table;
258  /// How to mark the map.
259  const enum_mark_columns mark;
260 };
261 
262 /**
263  Class used as argument to Item::walk() together with used_tables_for_level()
264 */
265 class Used_tables {
266  public:
267  explicit Used_tables(SELECT_LEX *select) : select(select), used_tables(0) {}
268 
269  SELECT_LEX *const select; ///< Level for which data is accumulated
270  table_map used_tables; ///< Accumulated used tables data
271 };

273 /*************************************************************************/
274 
275 /**
276  Storage for name strings.
277  Enpowers Simple_cstring with allocation routines from the sql_strmake family.
278 
279  This class must stay as small as possible as we often
280  pass it into functions using call-by-value evaluation.
281 
282  Don't add new members or virual methods into this class!
283 */
284 class Name_string : public Simple_cstring {
285  private:
286  void set_or_copy(const char *str, size_t length, bool is_null_terminated) {
287  if (is_null_terminated)
288  set(str, length);
289  else
290  copy(str, length);
291  }
292 
293  public:
294  Name_string() : Simple_cstring() {}
295  /*
296  Please do NOT add constructor Name_string(const char *str) !
297  It will involve hidden strlen() call, which can affect
298  performance negatively. Use Name_string(str, len) instead.
299  */
300  Name_string(const char *str, size_t length) : Simple_cstring(str, length) {}
301  Name_string(const LEX_STRING str) : Simple_cstring(str) {}
302  Name_string(const LEX_CSTRING str) : Simple_cstring(str) {}
303  Name_string(const char *str, size_t length, bool is_null_terminated)
304  : Simple_cstring() {
305  set_or_copy(str, length, is_null_terminated);
306  }
307  Name_string(const LEX_STRING str, bool is_null_terminated)
308  : Simple_cstring() {
309  set_or_copy(str.str, str.length, is_null_terminated);
310  }
311  /**
312  Allocate space using sql_strmake() or sql_strmake_with_convert().
313  */
314  void copy(const char *str, size_t length, const CHARSET_INFO *cs);
315  /**
316  Variants for copy(), for various argument combinations.
317  */
318  void copy(const char *str, size_t length) {
319  copy(str, length, system_charset_info);
320  }
321  void copy(const char *str) {
322  copy(str, (str ? strlen(str) : 0), system_charset_info);
323  }
324  void copy(const LEX_STRING lex) { copy(lex.str, lex.length); }
325  void copy(const LEX_STRING *lex) { copy(lex->str, lex->length); }
326  void copy(const Name_string str) { copy(str.ptr(), str.length()); }
327  /**
328  Compare name to another name in C string, case insensitively.
329  */
330  bool eq(const char *str) const {
331  DBUG_ASSERT(str && ptr());
332  return my_strcasecmp(system_charset_info, ptr(), str) == 0;
333  }
334  bool eq_safe(const char *str) const { return is_set() && str && eq(str); }
335  /**
336  Compare name to another name in Name_string, case insensitively.
337  */
338  bool eq(const Name_string name) const { return eq(name.ptr()); }
339  bool eq_safe(const Name_string name) const {
340  return is_set() && name.is_set() && eq(name);
341  }
342 };
343 
344 #define NAME_STRING(x) Name_string(STRING_WITH_LEN(x))
345 
346 extern const Name_string null_name_string;
347 
348 /**
349  Storage for Item names.
350  Adds "autogenerated" flag and warning functionality to Name_string.
351 */
352 class Item_name_string : public Name_string {
353  private:
354  bool m_is_autogenerated; /* indicates if name of this Item
355  was autogenerated or set by user */
356  public:
357  Item_name_string() : Name_string(), m_is_autogenerated(true) {}
358  Item_name_string(const Name_string name)
359  : Name_string(name), m_is_autogenerated(true) {}
360  /**
361  Set m_is_autogenerated flag to the given value.
362  */
363  void set_autogenerated(bool is_autogenerated) {
364  m_is_autogenerated = is_autogenerated;
365  }
366  /**
367  Return the auto-generated flag.
368  */
369  bool is_autogenerated() const { return m_is_autogenerated; }
370  using Name_string::copy;
371  /**
372  Copy name together with autogenerated flag.
373  Produce a warning if name was cut.
374  */
375  void copy(const char *str_arg, size_t length_arg, const CHARSET_INFO *cs_arg,
376  bool is_autogenerated_arg);
377 };
378 
379 /*
380  Instances of Name_resolution_context store the information necesary for
381  name resolution of Items and other context analysis of a query made in
382  fix_fields().
383 
384  This structure is a part of SELECT_LEX, a pointer to this structure is
385  assigned when an item is created (which happens mostly during parsing
386  (sql_yacc.yy)), but the structure itself will be initialized after parsing
387  is complete
388 
389  TODO: move subquery of INSERT ... SELECT and CREATE ... SELECT to
390  separate SELECT_LEX which allow to remove tricks of changing this
391  structure before and after INSERT/CREATE and its SELECT to make correct
392  field name resolution.
393 */
394 struct Name_resolution_context {
395  /*
396  The name resolution context to search in when an Item cannot be
397  resolved in this context (the context of an outer select)
398  */
399  Name_resolution_context *outer_context;
400  /// Link to next name res context with the same query block as the base
401  Name_resolution_context *next_context;
402 
403  /*
404  List of tables used to resolve the items of this context. Usually these
405  are tables from the FROM clause of SELECT statement. The exceptions are
406  INSERT ... SELECT and CREATE ... SELECT statements, where SELECT
407  subquery is not moved to a separate SELECT_LEX. For these types of
408  statements we have to change this member dynamically to ensure correct
409  name resolution of different parts of the statement.
410  */
411  TABLE_LIST *table_list;
412  /*
413  In most cases the two table references below replace 'table_list' above
414  for the purpose of name resolution. The first and last name resolution
415  table references allow us to search only in a sub-tree of the nested
416  join tree in a FROM clause. This is needed for NATURAL JOIN, JOIN ... USING
417  and JOIN ... ON.
418  */
419  TABLE_LIST *first_name_resolution_table;
420  /*
421  Last table to search in the list of leaf table references that begins
422  with first_name_resolution_table.
423  */
424  TABLE_LIST *last_name_resolution_table;
425 
426  /*
427  SELECT_LEX item belong to, in case of merged VIEW it can differ from
428  SELECT_LEX where item was created, so we can't use table_list/field_list
429  from there
430  */
431  SELECT_LEX *select_lex;
432 
433  /*
434  Processor of errors caused during Item name resolving, now used only to
435  hide underlying tables in errors about views (i.e. it substitute some
436  errors for views)
437  */
438  bool view_error_handler;
439  TABLE_LIST *view_error_handler_arg;
440 
441  /**
442  When true, items are resolved in this context against
443  SELECT_LEX::item_list, SELECT_lex::group_list and
444  this->table_list. If false, items are resolved only against
445  this->table_list.
446 
447  @see SELECT_LEX::item_list, SELECT_LEX::group_list
448  */
449  bool resolve_in_select_list;
450 
451  /*
452  Security context of this name resolution context. It's used for views
453  and is non-zero only if the view is defined with SQL SECURITY DEFINER.
454  */
455  Security_context *security_ctx;
456 
457  Name_resolution_context()
458  : outer_context(nullptr),
459  next_context(nullptr),
460  table_list(nullptr),
461  select_lex(nullptr),
462  view_error_handler_arg(nullptr),
463  security_ctx(nullptr) {
464  DBUG_PRINT("outer_field", ("creating ctx %p", this));
465  }
466 
467  void init() {
468  resolve_in_select_list = false;
469  view_error_handler = false;
470  first_name_resolution_table = nullptr;
471  last_name_resolution_table = nullptr;
472  }
473 
474  void resolve_in_table_list_only(TABLE_LIST *tables) {
475  table_list = first_name_resolution_table = tables;
476  resolve_in_select_list = false;
477  }
478 };
479 
480 /**
481  Struct used to pass around arguments to/from
482  check_function_as_value_generator
483 */
484 struct Check_function_as_value_generator_parameters {
485  Check_function_as_value_generator_parameters(
486  int default_error_code, Value_generator_source val_gen_src)
487  : err_code(default_error_code), source(val_gen_src) {}
488  /// the order of the column in table
489  int col_index{-1};
490  /// the error code found during check(if any)
491  int err_code;
492  /*
493  If it is a generated column, default expression or check constraint
494  expresion value generator.
495  */
496  Value_generator_source source;
497  /// the name of the function which is not allowed
498  const char *banned_function_name{nullptr};
499 
500  /// Return the correct error code, based on whether or not if we are checking
501  /// for disallowed functions in generated column expressions, in default
502  /// value expressions or in check constraint expression.
503  int get_unnamed_function_error_code() const {
504  return ((source == VGS_GENERATED_COLUMN)
505  ? ER_GENERATED_COLUMN_FUNCTION_IS_NOT_ALLOWED
506  : (source == VGS_DEFAULT_EXPRESSION)
507  ? ER_DEFAULT_VAL_GENERATED_FUNCTION_IS_NOT_ALLOWED
508  : ER_CHECK_CONSTRAINT_FUNCTION_IS_NOT_ALLOWED);
509  }
510 };
511 /*
512  Store and restore the current state of a name resolution context.
513 */
514 
515 class Name_resolution_context_state {
516  private:
517  TABLE_LIST *save_table_list;
518  TABLE_LIST *save_first_name_resolution_table;
519  TABLE_LIST *save_next_name_resolution_table;
520  bool save_resolve_in_select_list;
521  TABLE_LIST *save_next_local;
522 
523  public:
524  /* Save the state of a name resolution context. */
525  void save_state(Name_resolution_context *context, TABLE_LIST *table_list) {
526  save_table_list = context->table_list;
527  save_first_name_resolution_table = context->first_name_resolution_table;
528  save_resolve_in_select_list = context->resolve_in_select_list;
529  save_next_local = table_list->next_local;
530  save_next_name_resolution_table = table_list->next_name_resolution_table;
531  }
532 
533  /* Restore a name resolution context from saved state. */
534  void restore_state(Name_resolution_context *context, TABLE_LIST *table_list) {
535  table_list->next_local = save_next_local;
536  table_list->next_name_resolution_table = save_next_name_resolution_table;
537  context->table_list = save_table_list;
538  context->first_name_resolution_table = save_first_name_resolution_table;
539  context->resolve_in_select_list = save_resolve_in_select_list;
540  }
541 
542  void update_next_local(TABLE_LIST *table_list) {
543  save_next_local = table_list;
544  }
545 
546  TABLE_LIST *get_first_name_resolution_table() {
547  return save_first_name_resolution_table;
548  }
549 };
550 
551 /*
552  This enum is used to report information about monotonicity of function
553  represented by Item* tree.
554  Monotonicity is defined only for Item* trees that represent table
555  partitioning expressions (i.e. have no subqueries/user vars/dynamic parameters
556  etc etc). An Item* tree is assumed to have the same monotonicity properties
557  as its corresponding function F:
558 
559  [signed] longlong F(field1, field2, ...) {
560  put values of field_i into table record buffer;
561  return item->val_int();
562  }
563 
564  NOTE
565  At the moment function monotonicity is not well defined (and so may be
566  incorrect) for Item trees with parameters/return types that are different
567  from INT_RESULT, may be NULL, or are unsigned.
568  It will be possible to address this issue once the related partitioning bugs
569  (BUG#16002, BUG#15447, BUG#13436) are fixed.
570 
571  The NOT_NULL enums are used in TO_DAYS, since TO_DAYS('2001-00-00') returns
572  NULL which puts those rows into the NULL partition, but
573  '2000-12-31' < '2001-00-00' < '2001-01-01'. So special handling is needed
574  for this (see Bug#20577).
575 */
576 
577 typedef enum monotonicity_info {
578  NON_MONOTONIC, /* none of the below holds */
579  MONOTONIC_INCREASING, /* F() is unary and (x < y) => (F(x) <= F(y)) */
580  MONOTONIC_INCREASING_NOT_NULL, /* But only for valid/real x and y */
581  MONOTONIC_STRICT_INCREASING, /* F() is unary and (x < y) => (F(x) < F(y)) */
582  MONOTONIC_STRICT_INCREASING_NOT_NULL /* But only for valid/real x and y */
583 } enum_monotonicity_info;
584 
585 /**
586  A type for SQL-like 3-valued Booleans: true/false/unknown.
587 */
588 class Bool3 {
589  public:
590  /// @returns an instance set to "FALSE"
591  static const Bool3 false3() { return Bool3(v_FALSE); }
592  /// @returns an instance set to "UNKNOWN"
593  static const Bool3 unknown3() { return Bool3(v_UNKNOWN); }
594  /// @returns an instance set to "TRUE"
595  static const Bool3 true3() { return Bool3(v_TRUE); }
596 
597  bool is_true() const { return m_val == v_TRUE; }
598  bool is_unknown() const { return m_val == v_UNKNOWN; }
599  bool is_false() const { return m_val == v_FALSE; }
600 
601  private:
602  enum value { v_FALSE, v_UNKNOWN, v_TRUE };
603  /// This is private; instead, use false3()/etc.
604  Bool3(value v) : m_val(v) {}
605 
606  value m_val;
607  /*
608  No operator to convert Bool3 to bool (or int) - intentionally: how
609  would you map unknown3 to true/false?
610  It is because we want to block such conversions that Bool3 is a class
611  instead of a plain enum.
612  */
613 };
614 
615 /**
616  Type properties, used to collect type information for later assignment
617  to an Item object. The object stores attributes signedness, max length
618  and collation. However, precision and scale (for decimal numbers) and
619  fractional second precision (for time and datetime) are not stored,
620  since any type derived from this object will have default values for these
621  attributes.
622 */
623 class Type_properties {
624  public:
625  /// Constructor for any signed numeric type or date type
626  /// Defaults are provided for attributes like signedness and max length
627  Type_properties(enum_field_types type_arg)
628  : m_type(type_arg),
629  m_unsigned_flag(false),
630  m_max_length(0),
631  m_collation(&my_charset_numeric, DERIVATION_NUMERIC) {
632  DBUG_ASSERT(type_arg != MYSQL_TYPE_VARCHAR && type_arg != MYSQL_TYPE_JSON);
633  }
634  /// Constructor for any numeric type, with explicit signedness
635  Type_properties(enum_field_types type_arg, bool unsigned_arg)
636  : m_type(type_arg),
637  m_unsigned_flag(unsigned_arg),
638  m_max_length(0),
639  m_collation(&my_charset_numeric, DERIVATION_NUMERIC) {
640  DBUG_ASSERT(is_numeric_type(type_arg) || type_arg == MYSQL_TYPE_BIT);
641  }
642  /// Constructor for character type, with explicit character set.
643  /// Default length/max length is provided.
644  Type_properties(enum_field_types type_arg, const CHARSET_INFO *charset)
645  : m_type(type_arg),
646  m_unsigned_flag(false),
647  m_max_length(0),
648  m_collation(charset, DERIVATION_COERCIBLE) {}
649  /// Constructor for Item
650  Type_properties(Item &item);
651  const enum_field_types m_type;
652  const bool m_unsigned_flag;
653  const uint32 m_max_length;
654  const DTCollation m_collation;
655 };
656 
657 /*************************************************************************/
658 
659 class sp_rcontext;
660 
661 class Settable_routine_parameter {
662  public:
663  Settable_routine_parameter() {}
664  virtual ~Settable_routine_parameter() {}
665  /**
666  Set required privileges for accessing the parameter.
667 
668  @param privilege The required privileges for this field, with the
669  following alternatives:
670  MODE_IN - SELECT_ACL
671  MODE_OUT - UPDATE_ACL
672  MODE_INOUT - SELECT_ACL | UPDATE_ACL
673  */
674  virtual void set_required_privilege(ulong privilege MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {}
675 
676  /*
677  Set parameter value.
678 
679  SYNOPSIS
680  set_value()
681  thd thread handle
682  ctx context to which parameter belongs (if it is local
683  variable).
684  it item which represents new value
685 
686  RETURN
687  false if parameter value has been set,
688  true if error has occurred.
689  */
690  virtual bool set_value(THD *thd, sp_rcontext *ctx, Item **it) = 0;
691 
692  virtual void set_out_param_info(Send_field *info MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {}
693 
694  virtual const Send_field *get_out_param_info() const { return nullptr; }
695 };
696 
697 /*
698  Analyzer function
699  SYNOPSIS
700  argp in/out IN: Analysis parameter
701  OUT: Parameter to be passed to the transformer
702 
703  RETURN
704  true Invoke the transformer
705  false Don't do it
706 
707 */
708 typedef bool (Item::*Item_analyzer)(uchar **argp);
709 
710 /**
711  Type for transformers used by Item::transform and Item::compile
712  @param arg Argument used by the transformer. Really a typeless pointer
713  in spite of the uchar type (historical reasons). The
714  transformer needs to cast this to the desired pointer type
715  @returns The transformed item
716 */
717 typedef Item *(Item::*Item_transformer)(uchar *arg);
718 typedef void (*Cond_traverser)(const Item *item, void *arg);
719 
720 /**
721  Utility mixin class to be able to walk() only parts of item trees.
722 
723  Used with PREFIX+POSTFIX walk: in the prefix call of the Item
724  processor, we process the item X, may decide that its children should not
725  be processed (just like if they didn't exist): processor calls stop_at(X)
726  for that. Then walk() goes to a child Y; the processor tests is_stopped(Y)
727  which returns true, so processor sees that it must not do any processing
728  and returns immediately. Finally, the postfix call to the processor on X
729  tests is_stopped(X) which returns "true" and understands that the
730  not-to-be-processed children have been skipped so calls restart(). Thus,
731  any sibling of X, any part of the Item tree not under X, can then be
732  processed.
733 */
734 class Item_tree_walker {
735  protected:
736  Item_tree_walker() : stopped_at_item(nullptr) {}
737  ~Item_tree_walker() { DBUG_ASSERT(!stopped_at_item); }
738  Item_tree_walker(const Item_tree_walker &) = delete;
739  Item_tree_walker &operator=(const Item_tree_walker &) = delete;
740 
741  /// Stops walking children of this item
742  void stop_at(const Item *i) {
743  DBUG_ASSERT(!stopped_at_item);
744  stopped_at_item = i;
745  }
746 
747  /**
748  @returns if we are stopped. If item 'i' is where we stopped, restarts the
749  walk for next items.
750  */
751  bool is_stopped(const Item *i) {
752  if (stopped_at_item) {
753  /*
754  Walking was disabled for a tree part rooted a one ancestor of 'i' or
755  rooted at 'i'.
756  */
757  if (stopped_at_item == i) {
758  /*
759  Walking was disabled for the tree part rooted at 'i'; we have now just
760  returned back to this root (POSTFIX call), left the tree part:
761  enable the walk again, for other tree parts.
762  */
763  stopped_at_item = nullptr;
764  }
765  // No further processing to do for this item:
766  return true;
767  }
768  return false;
769  }
770 
771  private:
772  const Item *stopped_at_item;
773 };
774 
775 class Item : public Parse_tree_node {
776  typedef Parse_tree_node super;
777 
778  friend class udf_handler;
779  virtual bool is_expensive_processor(uchar *) { return false; }
780 
781  protected:
782  /**
783  Sets the result value of the function an empty string, using the current
784  character set. No memory is allocated.
785  @retval A pointer to the str_value member.
786  */
787  String *make_empty_result() {
788  str_value.set("", 0, collation.collation);
789  return &str_value;
790  }
791 
792  public:
793  Item(const Item &) = delete;
794  void operator=(Item &) = delete;
795  static void *operator new(size_t size) noexcept {
796  return (*THR_MALLOC)->Alloc(size);
797  }
798  static void *operator new(size_t size, MEM_ROOT *mem_root,
799  const std::nothrow_t &arg MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)) =
800  std::nothrow) noexcept {
801  return mem_root->Alloc(size);
802  }
803 
804  static void operator delete(void *ptr MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
805  size_t size MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
806  TRASH(ptr, size);
807  }
808  static void operator delete(void *, MEM_ROOT *,
809  const std::nothrow_t &) noexcept {}
810 
811  enum Type {
812  INVALID_ITEM = 0,
813  FIELD_ITEM,
814  FUNC_ITEM,
815  SUM_FUNC_ITEM,
816  STRING_ITEM,
817  INT_ITEM,
818  REAL_ITEM,
819  NULL_ITEM,
820  VARBIN_ITEM,
821  COPY_STR_ITEM,
822  FIELD_AVG_ITEM,
823  DEFAULT_VALUE_ITEM,
824  PROC_ITEM,
825  COND_ITEM,
826  REF_ITEM,
827  FIELD_STD_ITEM,
828  FIELD_VARIANCE_ITEM,
829  INSERT_VALUE_ITEM,
830  SUBSELECT_ITEM,
831  ROW_ITEM,
832  CACHE_ITEM,
833  TYPE_HOLDER,
834  PARAM_ITEM,
835  TRIGGER_FIELD_ITEM,
836  DECIMAL_ITEM,
837  XPATH_NODESET,
838  XPATH_NODESET_CMP,
839  VIEW_FIXER_ITEM,
840  FIELD_BIT_ITEM,
841  VALUES_COLUMN_ITEM
842  };
843 
844  enum cond_result { COND_UNDEF, COND_OK, COND_TRUE, COND_FALSE };
845 
846  enum traverse_order { POSTFIX, PREFIX };
847 
848  /// How to cache constant JSON data
849  enum enum_const_item_cache {
850  /// Don't cache
851  CACHE_NONE = 0,
852  /// Source data is a JSON string, parse and cache result
853  CACHE_JSON_VALUE,
854  /// Source data is SQL scalar, convert and cache result
855  CACHE_JSON_ATOM
856  };
857 
858  enum Bool_test ///< Modifier for result transformation
859  { BOOL_IS_TRUE = 0x00,
860  BOOL_IS_FALSE = 0x01,
861  BOOL_IS_UNKNOWN = 0x02,
862  BOOL_NOT_TRUE = 0x03,
863  BOOL_NOT_FALSE = 0x04,
864  BOOL_NOT_UNKNOWN = 0x05,
865  BOOL_IDENTITY = 0x06,
866  BOOL_NEGATED = 0x07,
867  BOOL_ALWAYS_TRUE = 0x08,
868  BOOL_ALWAYS_FALSE = 0x09,
869  };
870 
871  // Return the default data type for a given result type
872  static enum_field_types result_to_type(Item_result result) {
873  switch (result) {
874  case INT_RESULT:
875  return MYSQL_TYPE_LONGLONG;
876  case DECIMAL_RESULT:
877  return MYSQL_TYPE_NEWDECIMAL;
878  case REAL_RESULT:
879  return MYSQL_TYPE_DOUBLE;
880  case STRING_RESULT:
881  return MYSQL_TYPE_VARCHAR;
882  case INVALID_RESULT:
883  return MYSQL_TYPE_INVALID;
884  case ROW_RESULT:
885  default:
886  DBUG_ASSERT(false);
887  }
888  return MYSQL_TYPE_INVALID;
889  }
890 
891  // Return the default result type for a given data type
892  static Item_result type_to_result(enum_field_types type) {
893  switch (type) {
894  case MYSQL_TYPE_TINY:
895  case MYSQL_TYPE_SHORT:
896  case MYSQL_TYPE_INT24:
897  case MYSQL_TYPE_LONG:
898  case MYSQL_TYPE_LONGLONG:
899  case MYSQL_TYPE_BOOL:
900  case MYSQL_TYPE_BIT:
901  case MYSQL_TYPE_YEAR:
902  return INT_RESULT;
903  case MYSQL_TYPE_NEWDECIMAL:
904  case MYSQL_TYPE_DECIMAL:
905  return DECIMAL_RESULT;
906  case MYSQL_TYPE_FLOAT:
907  case MYSQL_TYPE_DOUBLE:
908  return REAL_RESULT;
909  case MYSQL_TYPE_VARCHAR:
910  case MYSQL_TYPE_VAR_STRING:
911  case MYSQL_TYPE_STRING:
912  case MYSQL_TYPE_TINY_BLOB:
913  case MYSQL_TYPE_MEDIUM_BLOB:
914  case MYSQL_TYPE_LONG_BLOB:
915  case MYSQL_TYPE_BLOB:
916  case MYSQL_TYPE_GEOMETRY:
917  case MYSQL_TYPE_JSON:
918  case MYSQL_TYPE_ENUM:
919  case MYSQL_TYPE_SET:
920  return STRING_RESULT;
921  case MYSQL_TYPE_TIMESTAMP:
922  case MYSQL_TYPE_DATE:
923  case MYSQL_TYPE_TIME:
924  case MYSQL_TYPE_DATETIME:
925  case MYSQL_TYPE_NEWDATE:
926  case MYSQL_TYPE_TIMESTAMP2:
927  case MYSQL_TYPE_DATETIME2:
928  case MYSQL_TYPE_TIME2:
929  return STRING_RESULT;
930  case MYSQL_TYPE_INVALID:
931  return INVALID_RESULT;
932  case MYSQL_TYPE_NULL:
933  case MYSQL_TYPE_TYPED_ARRAY:
934  break;
935  }
936  DBUG_ASSERT(false);
937  return INVALID_RESULT;
938  }
939 
940  /**
941  Provide data type for a user or system variable, based on the type of
942  the item that is assigned to the variable.
943 
944  @note MYSQL_TYPE_VARCHAR is returned for all string types, but must be
945  further adjusted based on maximum string length by the caller.
946 
947  @param src_type Source type that variable's type is derived from
948  */
949  static enum_field_types type_for_variable(enum_field_types src_type) {
950  switch (src_type) {
951  case MYSQL_TYPE_BOOL:
952  case MYSQL_TYPE_TINY:
953  case MYSQL_TYPE_SHORT:
954  case MYSQL_TYPE_INT24:
955  case MYSQL_TYPE_LONG:
956  case MYSQL_TYPE_LONGLONG:
957  case MYSQL_TYPE_BIT:
958  return MYSQL_TYPE_LONGLONG;
959  case MYSQL_TYPE_DECIMAL:
960  case MYSQL_TYPE_NEWDECIMAL:
961  return MYSQL_TYPE_NEWDECIMAL;
962  case MYSQL_TYPE_FLOAT:
963  case MYSQL_TYPE_DOUBLE:
964  return MYSQL_TYPE_DOUBLE;
965  case MYSQL_TYPE_VARCHAR:
966  case MYSQL_TYPE_VAR_STRING:
967  case MYSQL_TYPE_STRING:
968  return MYSQL_TYPE_VARCHAR;
969  case MYSQL_TYPE_YEAR:
970  return MYSQL_TYPE_LONGLONG;
971  case MYSQL_TYPE_TIMESTAMP:
972  case MYSQL_TYPE_DATE:
973  case MYSQL_TYPE_TIME:
974  case MYSQL_TYPE_DATETIME:
975  case MYSQL_TYPE_NEWDATE:
976  case MYSQL_TYPE_TIMESTAMP2:
977  case MYSQL_TYPE_DATETIME2:
978  case MYSQL_TYPE_TIME2:
979  case MYSQL_TYPE_JSON:
980  case MYSQL_TYPE_ENUM:
981  case MYSQL_TYPE_SET:
982  case MYSQL_TYPE_GEOMETRY:
983  case MYSQL_TYPE_NULL:
984  case MYSQL_TYPE_TINY_BLOB:
985  case MYSQL_TYPE_BLOB:
986  case MYSQL_TYPE_MEDIUM_BLOB:
987  case MYSQL_TYPE_LONG_BLOB:
988  return MYSQL_TYPE_VARCHAR;
989  case MYSQL_TYPE_INVALID:
990  case MYSQL_TYPE_TYPED_ARRAY:
991  return MYSQL_TYPE_INVALID;
992  }
993  DBUG_ASSERT(false);
994  return MYSQL_TYPE_NULL;
995  }
996 
997  /// Item constructor for general use.
998  Item();
999 
1000  /**
1001  Constructor used by Item_field, Item_ref & aggregate functions.
1002  Used for duplicating lists in processing queries with temporary tables.
1003 
1004  Also used for Item_cond_and/Item_cond_or for creating top AND/OR structure
1005  of WHERE clause to protect it of optimisation changes in prepared statements
1006  */
1007  Item(THD *thd, const Item *item);
1008 
1009  /**
1010  Parse-time context-independent constructor.
1011 
1012  This constructor and caller constructors of child classes must not
1013  access/change thd->lex (including thd->lex->current_select(),
1014  thd->m_parser_state etc structures).
1015 
1016  If we need to finalize the construction of the object, then we move
1017  all context-sensitive code to the itemize() virtual function.
1018 
1019  The POS parameter marks this constructor and other context-independent
1020  constructors of child classes for easy recognition/separation from other
1021  (context-dependent) constructors.
1022  */
1023  explicit Item(const POS &);
1024 
1025  ~Item() override {
1026 #ifdef EXTRA_DEBUG
1027  item_name.set(0);
1028 #endif
1029  } /*lint -e1509 */
1030 
1031  private:
1032  /*
1033  Hide the contextualize*() functions: call/override the itemize()
1034  in Item class tree instead.
1035  */
1036  bool contextualize(Parse_context *) override {
1037  DBUG_ASSERT(0);
1038  return true;
1039  }
1040 
1041  protected:
1042  /**
1043  Helper function to skip itemize() for grammar-allocated items
1044 
1045  @param [out] res pointer to "this"
1046 
1047  @retval true can skip itemize()
1048  @retval false can't skip: the item is allocated directly by the parser
1049  */
1050  bool skip_itemize(Item **res) {
1051  *res = this;
1052  return !is_parser_item;
1053  }
1054 
1055  /*
1056  Checks if the function should return binary result based on the items
1057  provided as parameter.
1058  Function should only be used by Item_bit_func*
1059 
1060  @param a item to check
1061  @param b item to check, may be nullptr
1062 
1063  @returns true if binary result.
1064  */
1065  static bool bit_func_returns_binary(const Item *a, const Item *b);
1066 
1067  public:
1068  /**
1069  The same as contextualize() but with additional parameter
1070 
1071  This function finalize the construction of Item objects (see the Item(POS)
1072  constructor): we can access/change parser contexts from the itemize()
1073  function.
1074 
1075  @param pc current parse context
1076  @param [out] res pointer to "this" or to a newly allocated
1077  replacement object to use in the Item tree instead
1078 
1079  @retval false success
1080  @retval true syntax/OOM/etc error
1081  */
1082  virtual bool itemize(Parse_context *pc, Item **res);
1083 
1084  void rename(char *new_name);
1085  void init_make_field(Send_field *tmp_field, enum enum_field_types type);
1086  /**
1087  Called for every Item after use (preparation and execution).
1088  Release all allocated resources, such as dynamic memory.
1089  Prepare for new execution by clearing cached values.
1090  Do not remove values allocated during preparation, destructor handles this.
1091  */
1092  virtual void cleanup() { marker = MARKER_NONE; }
1093  virtual void make_field(Send_field *field);
1094  virtual Field *make_string_field(TABLE *table) const;
1095  virtual bool fix_fields(THD *, Item **);
1096  /**
1097  Fix after tables have been moved from one select_lex level to the parent
1098  level, e.g by semijoin conversion.
1099  Basically re-calculate all attributes dependent on the tables.
1100 
1101  @param parent_select select_lex that tables are moved to.
1102  @param removed_select select_lex that tables are moved away from,
1103  child of parent_select.
1104  */
1105  virtual void fix_after_pullout(
1106  SELECT_LEX *parent_select MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
1107  SELECT_LEX *removed_select MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {}
1108  /*
1109  should be used in case where we are sure that we do not need
1110  complete fix_fields() procedure.
1111  */
1112  inline void quick_fix_field() { fixed = true; }
1113  virtual void set_can_use_prefix_key() {}
1114 
1115  /**
1116  Propagate data type specifications into parameters and user variables.
1117  If item has descendants, propagate type recursively into these.
1118 
1119  @param thd thread handler
1120  @param type Data type properties that are propagated
1121 
1122  @returns false if success, true if error
1123  */
1124  virtual bool propagate_type(THD *thd MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
1125  const Type_properties &type
1126  MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
1127  return false;
1128  }
1129 
1130  /**
1131  Wrapper for easier calling of propagate_type(const Type_properties &).
1132  @param thd thread handler
1133  @param def type to make Type_properties object
1134  @param pin if true: also mark the type as pinned
1135  @param inherit if true: also mark the type as inherited
1136 
1137  @returns false if success, true if error
1138  */
1139  bool propagate_type(THD *thd, enum_field_types def = MYSQL_TYPE_VARCHAR,
1140  bool pin = false, bool inherit = false) {
1141  /*
1142  Propagate supplied type if types have not yet been assigned to expression,
1143  or type is pinned, in which case the supplied type overrides the
1144  actual type of parameters. Note we do not support "pinning" of
1145  expressions containing parameters, only standalone parameters,
1146  but this is a very minor problem.
1147  */
1148  if (data_type() != MYSQL_TYPE_INVALID && !(pin && type() == PARAM_ITEM))
1149  return false;
1150  if (propagate_type(thd,
1151  (def == MYSQL_TYPE_VARCHAR)
1152  ? Type_properties(def, Item::default_charset())
1153  : (def == MYSQL_TYPE_JSON)
1154  ? Type_properties(def, &my_charset_utf8mb4_bin)
1155  : Type_properties(def)))
1156  return true;
1157  if (pin) pin_data_type();
1158  if (inherit) set_data_type_inherited();
1159 
1160  return false;
1161  }
1162 
1163  /**
1164  For Items with data type JSON, mark that a string argument is treated
1165  as a scalar JSON value. Only relevant for the Item_param class.
1166  */
1167  virtual void mark_json_as_scalar() {}
1168  virtual bool json_as_scalar() const { return false; }
1169 
1170  protected:
1171  /**
1172  Helper function which does all of the work for
1173  save_in_field(Field*, bool), except some error checking common to
1174  all subclasses, which is performed by save_in_field() itself.
1175 
1176  Subclasses that need to specialize the behaviour of
1177  save_in_field(), should override this function instead of
1178  save_in_field().
1179 
1180  @param[in,out] field the field to save the item into
1181  @param no_conversions whether or not to allow conversions of the value
1182 
1183  @return the status from saving into the field
1184  @retval TYPE_OK item saved without any errors or warnings
1185  @retval != TYPE_OK there were errors or warnings when saving the item
1186  */
1187  virtual type_conversion_status save_in_field_inner(Field *field,
1188  bool no_conversions);
1189 
1190  public:
1191  /**
1192  Save the item into a field but do not emit any warnings.
1193 
1194  @param field field to save the item into
1195  @param no_conversions whether or not to allow conversions of the value
1196 
1197  @return the status from saving into the field
1198  @retval TYPE_OK item saved without any issues
1199  @retval != TYPE_OK there were issues saving the item
1200  */
1201  type_conversion_status save_in_field_no_warnings(Field *field,
1202  bool no_conversions);
1203  /**
1204  Save a temporal value in packed longlong format into a Field.
1205  Used in optimizer.
1206 
1207  Subclasses that need to specialize this function, should override
1208  save_in_field_inner().
1209 
1210  @param[in,out] field the field to save the item into
1211  @param no_conversions whether or not to allow conversions of the value
1212 
1213  @return the status from saving into the field
1214  @retval TYPE_OK item saved without any errors or warnings
1215  @retval != TYPE_OK there were errors or warnings when saving the item
1216  */
1217  type_conversion_status save_in_field(Field *field, bool no_conversions);
1218 
1219  virtual void save_org_in_field(Field *field) { save_in_field(field, true); }
1220 
1221  virtual bool send(Protocol *protocol, String *str);
1222  bool evaluate(THD *thd, String *str);
1223  virtual bool eq(const Item *, bool binary_cmp) const;
1224  virtual Item_result result_type() const { return REAL_RESULT; }
1225  /**
1226  Result type when an item appear in a numeric context.
1227  See Field::numeric_context_result_type() for more comments.
1228  */
1229  virtual Item_result numeric_context_result_type() const {
1230  return ::numeric_context_result_type(data_type(), result_type(), decimals);
1231  }
1232  /**
1233  Similar to result_type() but makes DATE, DATETIME, TIMESTAMP
1234  pretend to be numbers rather than strings.
1235  */
1236  inline Item_result temporal_with_date_as_number_result_type() const {
1237  return is_temporal_with_date() ? (decimals ? DECIMAL_RESULT : INT_RESULT)
1238  : result_type();
1239  }
1240 
1241  /**
1242  Set data type for item as inherited.
1243  Non-empty implementation only for dynamic parameters.
1244  */
1245  virtual void set_data_type_inherited() {}
1246 
1247  /**
1248  Pin the data type for the item.
1249  Non-empty implementation only for dynamic parameters.
1250  */
1251  virtual void pin_data_type() {}
1252 
1253  /// Retrieve the derived data type of the Item.
1254  inline enum_field_types data_type() const {
1255  return static_cast<enum_field_types>(m_data_type);
1256  }
1257 
1258  /**
1259  Retrieve actual data type for an item. Equal to data_type() for
1260  all items, except parameters.
1261  */
1262  virtual enum_field_types actual_data_type() const { return data_type(); }
1263 
1264  /**
1265  Get the default data (output) type for the specific item.
1266  Important for some SQL functions that may deliver multiple result types,
1267  and is used to determine data type for function's parameters that cannot
1268  be type-resolved by looking at the context.
1269  An example of such function is '+', which may return INT, DECIMAL,
1270  DOUBLE, depending on arguments.
1271  On the contrary, many other functions have a fixed output type, usually
1272  set with set_data_type_XXX(), which overrides the value of
1273  default_data_type(). For example, COS always returns DOUBLE,
1274  */
1275  virtual enum_field_types default_data_type() const {
1276  // If data type has been set, the information returned here is irrelevant:
1277  DBUG_ASSERT(data_type() == MYSQL_TYPE_INVALID);
1278  return MYSQL_TYPE_VARCHAR;
1279  }
1280  /**
1281  Set the data type of the current Item. It is however recommended to
1282  use one of the type-specific setters if possible.
1283 
1284  @param data_type The data type of this Item.
1285  */
1286  inline void set_data_type(enum_field_types data_type) {
1287  m_data_type = static_cast<uint8>(data_type);
1288  }
1289 
1290  inline void set_data_type_bool() {
1291  set_data_type(MYSQL_TYPE_LONG);
1292  collation.set_numeric();
1293  max_length = 1;
1294  }
1295 
1296  /**
1297  Set the data type of the Item to be longlong.
1298  Maximum display width is set to be the maximum of a 64-bit integer,
1299  but it may be adjusted later. The unsigned property is not affected.
1300  */
1301  inline void set_data_type_longlong() {
1302  set_data_type(MYSQL_TYPE_LONGLONG);
1303  collation.set_numeric();
1304  fix_char_length(21);
1305  }
1306 
1307  /**
1308  Set the data type of the Item to be decimal.
1309  The unsigned property must have been set before calling this function.
1310 
1311  @param precision Number of digits of precision
1312  @param dec Number of digits after decimal point.
1313  */
1314  inline void set_data_type_decimal(uint8 precision, uint8 dec) {
1315  set_data_type(MYSQL_TYPE_NEWDECIMAL);
1316  collation.set_numeric();
1317  decimals = dec;
1318  fix_char_length(my_decimal_precision_to_length_no_truncation(
1319  precision, dec, unsigned_flag));
1320  }
1321 
1322  /// Set the data type of the Item to be double precision floating point.
1323  inline void set_data_type_double() {
1324  set_data_type(MYSQL_TYPE_DOUBLE);
1325  decimals = DECIMAL_NOT_SPECIFIED;
1326  max_length = float_length(decimals);
1327  collation.set_numeric();
1328  }
1329 
1330  /// Set the data type of the Item to be single precision floating point.
1331  inline void set_data_type_float() {
1332  set_data_type(MYSQL_TYPE_FLOAT);
1333  decimals = DECIMAL_NOT_SPECIFIED;
1334  max_length = float_length(decimals);
1335  collation.set_numeric();
1336  }
1337 
1338  /**
1339  Set the Item to be variable length string. Actual type is determined from
1340  maximum string size. Collation must have been set before calling function.
1341 
1342  @param max_l Maximum number of characters in string
1343  */
1344  inline void set_data_type_string(uint32 max_l) {
1345  max_length = max_l * collation.collation->mbmaxlen;
1346  decimals = DECIMAL_NOT_SPECIFIED;
1347  if (max_length <= Field::MAX_VARCHAR_WIDTH)
1348  set_data_type(MYSQL_TYPE_VARCHAR);
1349  else if (max_length <= Field::MAX_MEDIUM_BLOB_WIDTH)
1350  set_data_type(MYSQL_TYPE_MEDIUM_BLOB);
1351  else
1352  set_data_type(MYSQL_TYPE_LONG_BLOB);
1353  }
1354 
1355  /**
1356  Set the Item to be variable length string. Like function above, but with
1357  larger string length precision.
1358 
1359  @param max_char_length_arg Maximum number of characters in string
1360  */
1361  inline void set_data_type_string(ulonglong max_char_length_arg) {
1362  ulonglong max_result_length =
1363  max_char_length_arg * collation.collation->mbmaxlen;
1364  if (max_result_length > MAX_BLOB_WIDTH) {
1365  max_result_length = MAX_BLOB_WIDTH;
1366  maybe_null = true;
1367  }
1368  set_data_type_string(
1369  uint32(max_result_length / collation.collation->mbmaxlen));
1370  }
1371 
1372  /**
1373  Set the Item to be variable length string. Like function above, but will
1374  also set character set and collation.
1375 
1376  @param max_l Maximum number of characters in string
1377  @param cs Pointer to character set and collation struct
1378  */
1379  inline void set_data_type_string(uint32 max_l, const CHARSET_INFO *cs) {
1380  collation.collation = cs;
1381  set_data_type_string(max_l);
1382  }
1383 
1384  /**
1385  Set the Item to be variable length string. Like function above, but will
1386  also set full collation information.
1387 
1388  @param max_l Maximum number of characters in string
1389  @param coll Ref to collation data, including derivation and repertoire
1390  */
1391  inline void set_data_type_string(uint32 max_l, const DTCollation &coll) {
1392  collation.set(coll);
1393  set_data_type_string(max_l);
1394  }
1395 
1396  /**
1397  Set the Item to be fixed length string. Collation must have been set
1398  before calling function.
1399 
1400  @param max_l Number of characters in string
1401  */
1402  inline void set_data_type_char(uint32 max_l) {
1403  DBUG_ASSERT(max_l <= MAX_CHAR_WIDTH);
1404  max_length = max_l * collation.collation->mbmaxlen;
1405  decimals = DECIMAL_NOT_SPECIFIED;
1406  set_data_type(MYSQL_TYPE_STRING);
1407  }
1408 
1409  /**
1410  Set the Item to be fixed length string. Like function above, but will
1411  also set character set and collation.
1412 
1413  @param max_l Maximum number of characters in string
1414  @param cs Pointer to character set and collation struct
1415  */
1416  inline void set_data_type_char(uint32 max_l, const CHARSET_INFO *cs) {
1417  collation.collation = cs;
1418  set_data_type_char(max_l);
1419  }
1420 
1421  /**
1422  Set the Item to be of BLOB type.
1423 
1424  @param max_l Maximum number of bytes in data type
1425  */
1426  inline void set_data_type_blob(uint32 max_l) {
1427  set_data_type(MYSQL_TYPE_LONG_BLOB);
1428  max_length = max_l;
1429  decimals = DECIMAL_NOT_SPECIFIED;
1430  }
1431 
1432  /// Set all type properties for Item of DATE type.
1433  inline void set_data_type_date() {
1434  set_data_type(MYSQL_TYPE_DATE);
1435  collation.set_numeric();
1436  decimals = 0;
1437  max_length = MAX_DATE_WIDTH;
1438  }
1439 
1440  /**
1441  Set all type properties for Item of TIME type.
1442 
1443  @param fsp Fractional seconds precision
1444  */
1445  inline void set_data_type_time(uint8 fsp) {
1446  set_data_type(MYSQL_TYPE_TIME);
1447  collation.set_numeric();
1448  decimals = fsp;
1449  max_length = MAX_TIME_WIDTH + fsp + (fsp > 0 ? 1 : 0);
1450  }
1451 
1452  /**
1453  Set all properties for Item of DATETIME type.
1454 
1455  @param fsp Fractional seconds precision
1456  */
1457  inline void set_data_type_datetime(uint8 fsp) {
1458  set_data_type(MYSQL_TYPE_DATETIME);
1459  collation.set_numeric();
1460  decimals = fsp;
1461  max_length = MAX_DATETIME_WIDTH + fsp + (fsp > 0 ? 1 : 0);
1462  }
1463 
1464  /**
1465  Set all properties for Item of TIMESTAMP type.
1466 
1467  @param fsp Fractional seconds precision
1468  */
1469  inline void set_data_type_timestamp(uint8 fsp) {
1470  set_data_type(MYSQL_TYPE_TIMESTAMP);
1471  collation.set_numeric();
1472  decimals = fsp;
1473  max_length = MAX_DATETIME_WIDTH + fsp + (fsp > 0 ? 1 : 0);
1474  }
1475 
1476  /**
1477  Set the data type of the Item to be GEOMETRY.
1478  */
1479  void set_data_type_geometry() {
1480  set_data_type(MYSQL_TYPE_GEOMETRY);
1481  collation.set(&my_charset_bin, DERIVATION_IMPLICIT);
1482  decimals = DECIMAL_NOT_SPECIFIED;
1483  max_length = MAX_BLOB_WIDTH;
1484  }
1485  /**
1486  Set the data type of the Item to be JSON.
1487  */
1488  void set_data_type_json() {
1489  set_data_type(MYSQL_TYPE_JSON);
1490  collation.set(&my_charset_utf8mb4_bin, DERIVATION_IMPLICIT);
1491  decimals = DECIMAL_NOT_SPECIFIED;
1492  max_length = Field::MAX_LONG_BLOB_WIDTH;
1493  }
1494 
1495  /**
1496  Set the data type of the Item to be YEAR.
1497  */
1498  void set_data_type_year() {
1499  set_data_type(MYSQL_TYPE_YEAR);
1500  collation.set_numeric();
1501  fix_char_length(4);
1502  }
1503 
1504  /**
1505  Set the data type of the Item to be bit.
1506  */
1507  void set_data_type_bit() {
1508  set_data_type(MYSQL_TYPE_BIT);
1509  collation.set_numeric();
1510  fix_char_length(21);
1511  unsigned_flag = true;
1512  }
1513 
1514  /**
1515  Set data type properties of the item from the properties of another item.
1516 
1517  @param item Item to set data type properties from.
1518  */
1519  inline void set_data_type_from_item(const Item *item) {
1520  set_data_type(item->data_type());
1521  collation = item->collation;
1522  max_length = item->max_length;
1523  decimals = item->decimals;
1524  unsigned_flag = item->unsigned_flag;
1525  }
1526 
1527  /**
1528  Determine correct string field type, based on string length
1529 
1530  @param max_bytes Maximum string size, in number of bytes
1531  */
1532  static enum_field_types string_field_type(uint32 max_bytes) {
1533  if (max_bytes > Field::MAX_MEDIUM_BLOB_WIDTH)
1534  return MYSQL_TYPE_LONG_BLOB;
1535  else if (max_bytes > Field::MAX_VARCHAR_WIDTH)
1536  return MYSQL_TYPE_MEDIUM_BLOB;
1537  else
1538  return MYSQL_TYPE_VARCHAR;
1539  }
1540 
1541  virtual Item_result cast_to_int_type() const { return result_type(); }
1542  virtual enum Type type() const = 0;
1543 
1544  void aggregate_type(Bounds_checked_array<Item *> items);
1545 
1546  /*
1547  Return information about function monotonicity. See comment for
1548  enum_monotonicity_info for details. This function can only be called
1549  after fix_fields() call.
1550  */
1551  virtual enum_monotonicity_info get_monotonicity_info() const {
1552  return NON_MONOTONIC;
1553  }
1554 
1555  /*
1556  Convert "func_arg $CMP$ const" half-interval into "FUNC(func_arg) $CMP2$
1557  const2"
1558 
1559  SYNOPSIS
1560  val_int_endpoint()
1561  left_endp false <=> The interval is "x < const" or "x <= const"
1562  true <=> The interval is "x > const" or "x >= const"
1563 
1564  incl_endp IN false <=> the comparison is '<' or '>'
1565  true <=> the comparison is '<=' or '>='
1566  OUT The same but for the "F(x) $CMP$ F(const)" comparison
1567 
1568  DESCRIPTION
1569  This function is defined only for unary monotonic functions. The caller
1570  supplies the source half-interval
1571 
1572  x $CMP$ const
1573 
1574  The value of const is supplied implicitly as the value this item's
1575  argument, the form of $CMP$ comparison is specified through the
1576  function's arguments. The calle returns the result interval
1577 
1578  F(x) $CMP2$ F(const)
1579 
1580  passing back F(const) as the return value, and the form of $CMP2$
1581  through the out parameter. NULL values are assumed to be comparable and
1582  be less than any non-NULL values.
1583 
1584  RETURN
1585  The output range bound, which equal to the value of val_int()
1586  - If the value of the function is NULL then the bound is the
1587  smallest possible value of LLONG_MIN
1588  */
1589  virtual longlong val_int_endpoint(bool left_endp MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
1590  bool *incl_endp MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
1591  DBUG_ASSERT(0);
1592  return 0;
1593  }
1594 
1595  /* valXXX methods must return NULL or 0 or 0.0 if null_value is set. */
1596  /*
1597  Return double precision floating point representation of item.
1598 
1599  SYNOPSIS
1600  val_real()
1601 
1602  RETURN
1603  In case of NULL value return 0.0 and set null_value flag to true.
1604  If value is not null null_value flag will be reset to false.
1605  */
1606  virtual double val_real() = 0;
1607  /*
1608  Return integer representation of item.
1609 
1610  SYNOPSIS
1611  val_int()
1612 
1613  RETURN
1614  In case of NULL value return 0 and set null_value flag to true.
1615  If value is not null null_value flag will be reset to false.
1616  */
1617  virtual longlong val_int() = 0;
1618  /**
1619  Return date value of item in packed longlong format.
1620  */
1621  virtual longlong val_date_temporal();
1622  /**
1623  Return time value of item in packed longlong format.
1624  */
1625  virtual longlong val_time_temporal();
1626 
1627  /**
1628  Return date or time value of item in packed longlong format,
1629  depending on item field type.
1630  */
1631  longlong val_temporal_by_field_type() {
1632  if (data_type() == MYSQL_TYPE_TIME) return val_time_temporal();
1633  DBUG_ASSERT(is_temporal_with_date());
1634  return val_date_temporal();
1635  }
1636 
1637  /**
1638  Produces a key suitable for filesort. Most of the time, val_int() would
1639  suffice, but for temporal values, the packed value (as sent to the handler)
1640  is called for. It is also necessary that the value is in UTC. This function
1641  supplies just that.
1642 
1643  @return A sort key value.
1644  */
1645  longlong int_sort_key() {
1646  if (data_type() == MYSQL_TYPE_TIME) return val_time_temporal_at_utc();
1647  if (is_temporal_with_date()) return val_date_temporal_at_utc();
1648  return val_int();
1649  }
1650 
1651  /**
1652  Get date or time value in packed longlong format.
1653  Before conversion from MYSQL_TIME to packed format,
1654  the MYSQL_TIME value is rounded to "dec" fractional digits.
1655  */
1656  longlong val_temporal_with_round(enum_field_types type, uint8 dec);
1657 
1658  /*
1659  This is just a shortcut to avoid the cast. You should still use
1660  unsigned_flag to check the sign of the item.
1661  */
1662  inline ulonglong val_uint() { return (ulonglong)val_int(); }
1663  /*
1664  Return string representation of this item object.
1665 
1666  SYNOPSIS
1667  val_str()
1668  str an allocated buffer this or any nested Item object can use to
1669  store return value of this method.
1670 
1671  NOTE
1672  Buffer passed via argument should only be used if the item itself
1673  doesn't have an own String buffer. In case when the item maintains
1674  it's own string buffer, it's preferable to return it instead to
1675  minimize number of mallocs/memcpys.
1676  The caller of this method can modify returned string, but only in case
1677  when it was allocated on heap, (is_alloced() is true). This allows
1678  the caller to efficiently use a buffer allocated by a child without
1679  having to allocate a buffer of it's own. The buffer, given to
1680  val_str() as argument, belongs to the caller and is later used by the
1681  caller at it's own choosing.
1682  A few implications from the above:
1683  - unless you return a string object which only points to your buffer
1684  but doesn't manages it you should be ready that it will be
1685  modified.
1686  - even for not allocated strings (is_alloced() == false) the caller
1687  can change charset (see Item_func_{typecast/binary}. XXX: is this
1688  a bug?
1689  - still you should try to minimize data copying and return internal
1690  object whenever possible.
1691 
1692  RETURN
1693  In case of NULL value or error, return error_str() as this function will
1694  check if the return value may be null, and it will either set null_value
1695  to true and return nullptr or to false and it will return empty string.
1696  If value is not null set null_value flag to false before returning it.
1697  */
1698  virtual String *val_str(String *str) = 0;
1699 
1700  /*
1701  Returns string representation of this item in ASCII format.
1702 
1703  SYNOPSIS
1704  val_str_ascii()
1705  str - similar to val_str();
1706 
1707  NOTE
1708  This method is introduced for performance optimization purposes.
1709 
1710  1. val_str() result of some Items in string context
1711  depends on @@character_set_results.
1712  @@character_set_results can be set to a "real multibyte" character
1713  set like UCS2, UTF16, UTF32. (We'll use only UTF32 in the examples
1714  below for convenience.)
1715 
1716  So the default string result of such functions
1717  in these circumstances is real multi-byte character set, like UTF32.
1718 
1719  For example, all numbers in string context
1720  return result in @@character_set_results:
1721 
1722  SELECT CONCAT(20010101); -> UTF32
1723 
1724  We do sprintf() first (to get ASCII representation)
1725  and then convert to UTF32;
1726 
1727  So these kind "data sources" can use ASCII representation
1728  internally, but return multi-byte data only because
1729  @@character_set_results wants so.
1730  Therefore, conversion from ASCII to UTF32 is applied internally.
1731 
1732 
1733  2. Some other functions need in fact ASCII input.
1734 
1735  For example,
1736  inet_aton(), GeometryFromText(), Convert_TZ(), GET_FORMAT().
1737 
1738  Similar, fields of certain type, like DATE, TIME,
1739  when you insert string data into them, expect in fact ASCII input.
1740  If they get non-ASCII input, for example UTF32, they
1741  convert input from UTF32 to ASCII, and then use ASCII
1742  representation to do further processing.
1743 
1744 
1745  3. Now imagine we pass result of a data source of the first type
1746  to a data destination of the second type.
1747 
1748  What happens:
1749  a. data source converts data from ASCII to UTF32, because
1750  @@character_set_results wants so and passes the result to
1751  data destination.
1752  b. data destination gets UTF32 string.
1753  c. data destination converts UTF32 string to ASCII,
1754  because it needs ASCII representation to be able to handle data
1755  correctly.
1756 
1757  As a result we get two steps of unnecessary conversion:
1758  From ASCII to UTF32, then from UTF32 to ASCII.
1759 
1760  A better way to handle these situations is to pass ASCII
1761  representation directly from the source to the destination.
1762 
1763  This is why val_str_ascii() introduced.
1764 
1765  RETURN
1766  Similar to val_str()
1767  */
1768  virtual String *val_str_ascii(String *str);
1769 
1770  /*
1771  Return decimal representation of item with fixed point.
1772 
1773  SYNOPSIS
1774  val_decimal()
1775  decimal_buffer buffer which can be used by Item for returning value
1776  (but can be not)
1777 
1778  NOTE
1779  Returned value should not be changed if it is not the same which was
1780  passed via argument.
1781 
1782  RETURN
1783  Return pointer on my_decimal (it can be other then passed via argument)
1784  if value is not NULL (null_value flag will be reset to false).
1785  In case of NULL value it return 0 pointer and set null_value flag
1786  to true.
1787  */
1788  virtual my_decimal *val_decimal(my_decimal *decimal_buffer) = 0;
1789  /*
1790  Return boolean value of item.
1791 
1792  RETURN
1793  false value is false or NULL
1794  true value is true (not equal to 0)
1795  */
1796  virtual bool val_bool();
1797 
1798  /**
1799  Get a JSON value from an Item.
1800 
1801  All subclasses that can return a JSON value, should override this
1802  function. The function in the base class is not expected to be
1803  called. If it is called, it most likely means that some subclass
1804  is missing an override of val_json().
1805 
1806  @param[in,out] result The resulting Json_wrapper.
1807 
1808  @return false if successful, true on failure
1809  */
1810  /* purecov: begin deadcode */
1811  virtual bool val_json(Json_wrapper *result MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
1812  DBUG_ASSERT(false);
1813  my_error(ER_NOT_SUPPORTED_YET, MYF(0), "item type for JSON");
1814  return error_json();
1815  }
1816  /* purecov: end */
1817 
1818  /**
1819  Calculate the filter contribution that is relevant for table
1820  'filter_for_table' for this item.
1821 
1822  @param thd Thread handler
1823  @param filter_for_table The table we are calculating filter effect for
1824  @param read_tables Tables earlier in the join sequence.
1825  Predicates for table 'filter_for_table' that
1826  rely on values from these tables can be part of
1827  the filter effect.
1828  @param fields_to_ignore Fields in 'filter_for_table' that should not
1829  be part of the filter calculation. The filtering
1830  effect of these fields is already part of the
1831  calculation somehow (e.g. because there is a
1832  predicate "col = <const>", and the optimizer
1833  has decided to do ref access on 'col').
1834  @param rows_in_table The number of rows in table 'filter_for_table'
1835 
1836  @return the filtering effect (between 0 and 1) this
1837  Item contributes with.
1838  */
1839  virtual float get_filtering_effect(
1840  THD *thd MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
1841  table_map filter_for_table MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
1842  table_map read_tables MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
1843  const MY_BITMAP *fields_to_ignore MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
1844  double rows_in_table MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
1845  // Filtering effect cannot be calculated for a table already read.
1846  DBUG_ASSERT((read_tables & filter_for_table) == 0);
1847  return COND_FILTER_ALLPASS;
1848  }
1849 
1850  /**
1851  Get the value to return from val_json() in case of errors.
1852 
1853  @see Item::error_bool
1854 
1855  @return The value val_json() should return, which is true.
1856  */
1857  bool error_json() {
1858  null_value = maybe_null;
1859  return true;
1860  }
1861 
1862  /**
1863  Convert a non-temporal type to date
1864  */
1865  bool get_date_from_non_temporal(MYSQL_TIME *ltime, my_time_flags_t fuzzydate);
1866 
1867  /**
1868  Convert a non-temporal type to time
1869  */
1870  bool get_time_from_non_temporal(MYSQL_TIME *ltime);
1871 
1872  protected:
1873  /* Helper functions, see item_sum.cc */
1874  String *val_string_from_real(String *str);
1875  String *val_string_from_int(String *str);
1876  String *val_string_from_decimal(String *str);
1877  String *val_string_from_date(String *str);
1878  String *val_string_from_datetime(String *str);
1879  String *val_string_from_time(String *str);
1880  my_decimal *val_decimal_from_real(my_decimal *decimal_value);
1881  my_decimal *val_decimal_from_int(my_decimal *decimal_value);
1882  my_decimal *val_decimal_from_string(my_decimal *decimal_value);
1883  my_decimal *val_decimal_from_date(my_decimal *decimal_value);
1884  my_decimal *val_decimal_from_time(my_decimal *decimal_value);
1885  longlong val_int_from_decimal();
1886  longlong val_int_from_date();
1887  longlong val_int_from_time();
1888  longlong val_int_from_datetime();
1889  longlong val_int_from_string();
1890  double val_real_from_decimal();
1891  double val_real_from_string();
1892 
1893  /**
1894  Get the value to return from val_bool() in case of errors.
1895 
1896  This function is called from val_bool() when an error has occurred
1897  and we need to return something to abort evaluation of the
1898  item. The expected pattern in val_bool() is
1899 
1900  if (@<error condition@>)
1901  {
1902  my_error(...)
1903  return error_bool();
1904  }
1905 
1906  @return The value val_bool() should return.
1907  */
1908  bool error_bool() {
1909  null_value = maybe_null;
1910  return false;
1911  }
1912 
1913  /**
1914  Get the value to return from val_int() in case of errors.
1915 
1916  @see Item::error_bool
1917 
1918  @return The value val_int() should return.
1919  */
1920  int error_int() {
1921  null_value = maybe_null;
1922  return 0;
1923  }
1924 
1925  /**
1926  Get the value to return from val_real() in case of errors.
1927 
1928  @see Item::error_bool
1929 
1930  @return The value val_real() should return.
1931  */
1932  double error_real() {
1933  null_value = maybe_null;
1934  return 0.0;
1935  }
1936 
1937  /**
1938  Get the value to return from val_str() in case of errors.
1939 
1940  @see Item::error_bool
1941 
1942  @return The value val_str() should return.
1943  */
1944  String *error_str() {
1945  null_value = maybe_null;
1946  return null_value ? nullptr : make_empty_result();
1947  }
1948 
1949  /**
1950  Gets the value to return from val_str() when returning a NULL value.
1951  @return The value val_str() should return.
1952  */
1953  String *null_return_str() {
1954  DBUG_ASSERT(maybe_null);
1955  null_value = true;
1956  return nullptr;
1957  }
1958 
1959  /**
1960  Convert val_str() to date in MYSQL_TIME
1961  */
1962  bool get_date_from_string(MYSQL_TIME *ltime, my_time_flags_t flags);
1963  /**
1964  Convert val_real() to date in MYSQL_TIME
1965  */
1966  bool get_date_from_real(MYSQL_TIME *ltime, my_time_flags_t flags);
1967  /**
1968  Convert val_decimal() to date in MYSQL_TIME
1969  */
1970  bool get_date_from_decimal(MYSQL_TIME *ltime, my_time_flags_t flags);
1971  /**
1972  Convert val_int() to date in MYSQL_TIME
1973  */
1974  bool get_date_from_int(MYSQL_TIME *ltime, my_time_flags_t flags);
1975  /**
1976  Convert get_time() from time to date in MYSQL_TIME
1977  */
1978  bool get_date_from_time(MYSQL_TIME *ltime);
1979 
1980  /**
1981  Convert a numeric type to date
1982  */
1983  bool get_date_from_numeric(MYSQL_TIME *ltime, my_time_flags_t fuzzydate);
1984 
1985  /**
1986  Convert val_str() to time in MYSQL_TIME
1987  */
1988  bool get_time_from_string(MYSQL_TIME *ltime);
1989  /**
1990  Convert val_real() to time in MYSQL_TIME
1991  */
1992  bool get_time_from_real(MYSQL_TIME *ltime);
1993  /**
1994  Convert val_decimal() to time in MYSQL_TIME
1995  */
1996  bool get_time_from_decimal(MYSQL_TIME *ltime);
1997  /**
1998  Convert val_int() to time in MYSQL_TIME
1999  */
2000  bool get_time_from_int(MYSQL_TIME *ltime);
2001  /**
2002  Convert date to time
2003  */
2004  bool get_time_from_date(MYSQL_TIME *ltime);
2005  /**
2006  Convert datetime to time
2007  */
2008  bool get_time_from_datetime(MYSQL_TIME *ltime);
2009 
2010  /**
2011  Convert a numeric type to time
2012  */
2013  bool get_time_from_numeric(MYSQL_TIME *ltime);
2014 
2015  virtual longlong val_date_temporal_at_utc() { return val_date_temporal(); }
2016 
2017  virtual longlong val_time_temporal_at_utc() { return val_time_temporal(); }
2018 
2019  public:
2020  type_conversion_status save_time_in_field(Field *field);
2021  type_conversion_status save_date_in_field(Field *field);
2022  type_conversion_status save_str_value_in_field(Field *field, String *result);
2023 
2024  /**
2025  If this Item is being materialized into a temporary table, returns the
2026  field that is being materialized into. (Typically, this is the
2027  result_field members for items that have one.)
2028  */
2029  virtual Field *get_tmp_table_field() {
2030  DBUG_TRACE;
2031  return nullptr;
2032  }
2033  /* This is also used to create fields in CREATE ... SELECT: */
2034  virtual Field *tmp_table_field(TABLE *) { return nullptr; }
2035  virtual const char *full_name() const {
2036  return item_name.is_set() ? item_name.ptr() : "???";
2037  }
2038 
2039  /* bit map of tables used by item */
2040  virtual table_map used_tables() const { return (table_map)0L; }
2041 
2042  /*
2043  Return table map of tables that can't be NULL tables (tables that are
2044  used in a context where if they would contain a NULL row generated
2045  by a LEFT or RIGHT join, the item would not be true).
2046  This expression is used on WHERE item to determinate if a LEFT JOIN can be
2047  converted to a normal join.
2048  Generally this function should return used_tables() if the function
2049  would return null if any of the arguments are null
2050  As this is only used in the beginning of optimization, the value don't
2051  have to be updated in update_used_tables()
2052  */
2053  virtual table_map not_null_tables() const { return used_tables(); }
2054 
2055  /**
2056  Returns true if this is a simple constant item like an integer, not
2057  a constant expression. Used in the optimizer to propagate basic constants.
2058  It is assumed that val_xxx() does not modify the item's state for
2059  such items. It is also assumed that val_str() can be called with nullptr
2060  as argument as val_str() will return an internally cached const string.
2061  */
2062  virtual bool basic_const_item() const { return false; }
2063  /**
2064  @return cloned item if it is constant
2065  @retval nullptr if this is not const
2066  */
2067  virtual Item *clone_item() const { return nullptr; }
2068  virtual cond_result eq_cmp_result() const { return COND_OK; }
2069  inline uint float_length(uint decimals_par) const {
2070  return decimals != DECIMAL_NOT_SPECIFIED ? (DBL_DIG + 2 + decimals_par)
2071  : DBL_DIG + 8;
2072  }
2073  virtual uint decimal_precision() const;
2074  inline int decimal_int_part() const {
2075  return my_decimal_int_part(decimal_precision(), decimals);
2076  }
2077  /**
2078  TIME precision of the item: 0..6
2079  */
2080  virtual uint time_precision();
2081  /**
2082  DATETIME precision of the item: 0..6
2083  */
2084  virtual uint datetime_precision();
2085  /**
2086  Returns true if item is constant, regardless of query evaluation state.
2087  An expression is constant if it:
2088  - refers no tables.
2089  - refers no subqueries that refers any tables.
2090  - refers no non-deterministic functions.
2091  - refers no statement parameters.
2092  - contains no group expression under rollup
2093  */
2094  bool const_item() const { return (used_tables() == 0); }
2095  /**
2096  Returns true if item is constant during one query execution.
2097  If const_for_execution() is true but const_item() is false, value is
2098  not available before tables have been locked and parameters have been
2099  assigned values. This applies to
2100  - statement parameters
2101  - non-dependent subqueries
2102  - deterministic stored functions that contain SQL code.
2103  For items where the default implementation of used_tables() and
2104  const_item() are effective, const_item() will always return true.
2105  */
2106  bool const_for_execution() const {
2107  return !(used_tables() & ~INNER_TABLE_BIT);
2108  }
2109 
2110  /**
2111  Return true if this is a const item that may be evaluated in
2112  the current phase of statement processing.
2113  - No evaluation is performed when analyzing a view, otherwise:
2114  - Items that have the const_item() property can always be evaluated.
2115  - Items that have the const_for_execution() property can be evaluated when
2116  tables are locked (ie during optimization or execution).
2117 
2118  This function should be used in the following circumstances:
2119  - during preparation to check whether an item can be permanently transformed
2120  - to check that an item is constant in functions that may be used in both
2121  the preparation and optimization phases.
2122 
2123  This function should not be used by code that is called during optimization
2124  and/or execution only. Use const_for_execution() in this case.
2125  */
2126  bool may_evaluate_const(const THD *thd) const;
2127 
2128  /**
2129  This method is used for to:
2130  - to generate a view definition query (SELECT-statement);
2131  - to generate a SQL-query for EXPLAIN EXTENDED;
2132  - to generate a SQL-query to be shown in INFORMATION_SCHEMA;
2133  - to generate a SQL-query that looks like a prepared statement for
2134  query_rewrite
2135  - debug.
2136 
2137  For more information about view definition query, INFORMATION_SCHEMA
2138  query and why they should be generated from the Item-tree, @see
2139  mysql_register_view().
2140  */
2141  virtual void print(const THD *, String *str, enum_query_type) const {
2142  str->append(full_name());
2143  }
2144 
2145  void print_item_w_name(const THD *thd, String *,
2146  enum_query_type query_type) const;
2147  /**
2148  Prints the item when it's part of ORDER BY and GROUP BY.
2149  @param thd Thread handle
2150  @param str String to print to
2151  @param query_type How to format the item
2152  @param used_alias Whether item was referenced with alias.
2153  */
2154  void print_for_order(const THD *thd, String *str, enum_query_type query_type,
2155  bool used_alias) const;
2156 
2157  /**
2158  Updates used tables, not null tables information and accumulates
2159  properties up the item tree, cf. used_tables_cache, not_null_tables_cache
2160  and m_accum_properties.
2161  */
2162  virtual void update_used_tables() {}
2163 
2164  virtual void split_sum_func(THD *, Ref_item_array, mem_root_deque<Item *> *) {
2165  }
2166  /* Called for items that really have to be split */
2167  void split_sum_func2(THD *thd, Ref_item_array ref_item_array,
2168  mem_root_deque<Item *> *fields, Item **ref,
2169  bool skip_registered);
2170  virtual bool get_date(MYSQL_TIME *ltime, my_time_flags_t fuzzydate) = 0;
2171  virtual bool get_time(MYSQL_TIME *ltime) = 0;
2172  /**
2173  Get timestamp in "struct timeval" format.
2174  @retval false on success
2175  @retval true on error
2176  */
2177  virtual bool get_timeval(struct timeval *tm, int *warnings);
2178  /**
2179  The method allows to determine nullness of a complex expression
2180  without fully evaluating it, instead of calling val*() then
2181  checking null_value. Used in Item_func_isnull/Item_func_isnotnull
2182  and Item_sum_count/Item_sum_count_distinct.
2183  Any item which can be NULL must implement this method.
2184 
2185  @retval false if the expression is not NULL.
2186  @retval true if the expression is NULL, or evaluation caused an error.
2187  The null_value member is set according to the return value.
2188  */
2189  virtual bool is_null() { return false; }
2190 
2191  /**
2192  Make sure the null_value member has a correct value.
2193  null_value is set true also when evaluation causes error.
2194 
2195  @returns false if success, true if error
2196  */
2197  bool update_null_value();
2198 
2199  /**
2200  Apply the IS TRUE truth property, meaning that an UNKNOWN result and a
2201  FALSE result are treated the same.
2202 
2203  This property is applied e.g to all conditions in WHERE, HAVING and ON
2204  clauses, and is recursively applied to operands of AND, OR
2205  operators. Some items (currently AND and subquery predicates) may enable
2206  special optimizations when they have this property.
2207  */
2208  virtual void apply_is_true() {}
2209  /*
2210  set field of temporary table for Item which can be switched on temporary
2211  table during query processing (grouping and so on). @see
2212  Item_result_field.
2213  */
2214  virtual void set_result_field(Field *) {}
2215  virtual bool is_result_field() const { return false; }
2216  virtual Field *get_result_field() const { return nullptr; }
2217  virtual bool is_bool_func() const { return false; }
2218  /*
2219  Set value of aggregate function in case of no rows for grouping were found.
2220  Also used for subqueries with outer references in SELECT list.
2221  */
2222  virtual void no_rows_in_result() {}
2223  virtual Item *copy_or_same(THD *) { return this; }
2224  virtual Item *copy_andor_structure(THD *) { return this; }
2225  virtual Item *real_item() { return this; }
2226  /**
2227  If an Item is materialized in a temporary table, a different Item may have
2228  to be used in the part of the query that runs after the materialization.
2229  For instance, if the Item was an Item_field, the new Item_field needs to
2230  point into the temporary table instead of the original one, but if, on the
2231  other hand, the Item was a literal constant, it can be reused as-is.
2232  This function encapsulates these policies for the different kinds of Items.
2233  See also get_tmp_table_field().
2234 
2235  TODO: Document how aggregate functions (Item_sum) are handled.
2236  */
2237  virtual Item *get_tmp_table_item(THD *thd) { return copy_or_same(thd); }
2238 
2239  static const CHARSET_INFO *default_charset();
2240  virtual const CHARSET_INFO *compare_collation() const { return nullptr; }
2241 
2242  /*
2243  For backward compatibility, to make numeric
2244  data types return "binary" charset in client-side metadata.
2245  */
2246  virtual const CHARSET_INFO *charset_for_protocol() {
2247  return result_type() == STRING_RESULT ? collation.collation
2248  : &my_charset_bin;
2249  }
2250 
2251  /**
2252  Traverses a tree of Items in prefix and/or postfix order.
2253  Optionally walks into subqueries.
2254 
2255  @param processor processor function to be invoked per item
2256  returns true to abort traversal, false to continue
2257  @param walk controls how to traverse the item tree
2258  enum_walk::PREFIX: call processor before invoking
2259  children enum_walk::POSTFIX: call processor after invoking children
2260  enum_walk::SUBQUERY go down into subqueries
2261  walk values are bit-coded and may be combined.
2262  Omitting both enum_walk::PREFIX and enum_walk::POSTFIX
2263  is undefined behaviour.
2264  @param arg Optional pointer to a walk-specific object
2265 
2266  @retval false walk succeeded
2267  @retval true walk aborted
2268  by agreement, an error may have been reported
2269  */
2270 
2271  virtual bool walk(Item_processor processor,
2272  enum_walk walk MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)), uchar *arg) {
2273  return (this->*processor)(arg);
2274  }
2275 
2276  /** @see WalkItem */
2277  template <class T>
2278  bool walk_helper_thunk(uchar *arg) {
2279  return (*reinterpret_cast<T *>(arg))(this);
2280  }
2281 
2282  /**
2283  Perform a generic transformation of the Item tree, by adding zero or
2284  more additional Item objects to it.
2285 
2286  @param transformer Transformer function
2287  @param[in,out] arg Pointer to struct used by transformer function
2288 
2289  @returns Returned item tree after transformation, NULL if error
2290 
2291  Transformation is performed as follows:
2292 
2293  @code
2294  transform()
2295  {
2296  transform children if any;
2297  return this->*some_transformer(...);
2298  }
2299  @endcode
2300 
2301  Note that unlike Item::compile(), transform() does not support an analyzer
2302  function, ie. all children are unconditionally invoked.
2303 
2304  Item::transform() should handle all transformations during preparation.
2305  Notice that all transformations are permanent; they are not rolled back.
2306 
2307  Use Item::compile() to perform transformations during optimization.
2308  */
2309  virtual Item *transform(Item_transformer transformer, uchar *arg);
2310 
2311  /**
2312  Perform a generic "compilation" of the Item tree, ie transform the Item tree
2313  by adding zero or more Item objects to it.
2314 
2315  @param analyzer Analyzer function, see details section
2316  @param[in,out] arg_p Pointer to struct used by analyzer function
2317  @param transformer Transformer function, see details section
2318  @param[in,out] arg_t Pointer to struct used by transformer function
2319 
2320  @returns Returned item tree after transformation, NULL if error
2321 
2322  The process of this transformation is assumed to be as follows:
2323 
2324  @code
2325  compile()
2326  {
2327  if (this->*some_analyzer(...))
2328  {
2329  compile children if any;
2330  return this->*some_transformer(...);
2331  }
2332  else
2333  return this;
